body_html:
Thanks for writing this up! One tip: you can do

sudo xcode-select -s /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools

instead of removing XCode and

sudo xcode-select -s /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer

to revert it to the previous setting (xcode-select -p prints the current cmdline tools path).

If you don't have any uncommited changes (this is important - they would get removed) in pytorch sources you can use git clean -xfd to purge the repo to a state as if it was freshly cloned (all build artifacts gone).

Thanks for writing this up! One tip: you can do
sudo xcode-select -s /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools

instead of removing XCode and
sudo xcode-select -s /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer

to revert it to the previous setting (xcode-select -p prints the current cmdline tools path).

If you don't have any uncommited changes (this is important - they would get removed) in pytorch sources you can use git clean -xfd to purge the repo to a state as if it was freshly cloned (all build artifacts gone).
body:
Thanks for writing this up! One tip: you can do
```
sudo xcode-select -s /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools
```
instead of removing XCode and
```
sudo xcode-select -s /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer
```
to revert it to the previous setting (`xcode-select -p` prints the current cmdline tools path).

---

If you don't have any uncommited changes (**this is important - they would get removed**) in pytorch sources you can use `git clean -xfd` to purge the repo to a state as if it was freshly cloned (all build artifacts gone).
